0.user_question: Find the number of integer values of $k$ in the closed interval $[-500,500]$ for which the equation $\log(kx)=2\log(x+2)$ has exactly one real solution.

ost_step.1: Using logarithmic properties, rewrite the equation as $\log(k) - \log(x) = \log(x+2)$.
ost_step.3: For the logs to be equal, their arguments must also be equal: $\frac{k}{x} = x + 2$.
ost_step.4: Solve for $x$: $k = x^2 + 2x$. Rearrange into standard quadratic form: $x^2 + 2x - k = 0$.

direct_answer.text: To determine how many integers satisfy our condition ($f(x) = g(x)$, i.e., when does it cross once), look back to Rolle’s Theorem: If f $(a) = f $(b)  but   f′ $(c) ≠ 0 , then either function never intersect twice over [a, b] OR passes through zero infinitely often inside [a, b]. Here both functions intercept each other just once because derivative exists everywhere except maybe some isolated zeros/poles. Now focus main question about intersection happening ONCE within bounds −− what needs doing here ? Answer : Check whether discriminant under square root becomes nonnegative! Discriminate D=B²−4AC=(2)²−4(1)(−K)=4+4K≥0⇒ K≤−1 . All int­gers satisfying above inequality lie outside required range already implied by hint thus no need further check those ! Result follows directly hence count comes out same — single value being true & false depending upon sign change due partial roots crossing boundary ; therefore overall intersections occur TWICE whenever negative term appears among them while occurring NEITHER otherwise always maintaining consistency wrt initial assumption concerning existence degree difference

0.user_question: Find the number of integer values of $k$ in the closed interval $[-500,500]$ for which the equation $\log(kx)=2\log(x+2)$ has exactly one real solution.

direct_answer.text: To solve this problem, let's first simplify the logarithmic equation using properties of logs. Recall that $a\log(b)=\log(b^a)$, so our original equation becomes $\log((kx)^{1/2})=\log((x+2)^2)$. Taking exponents yields $(kx)^{1/2}=(x+2)^2$, squaring both sides produces $kx=x^2+4x+4$. Rearranging terms results in $x^2-(k-4)x+4=0$. Using Vieta's formulas, recall that the roots x1 & x2 satisfy -SumRootProduct=-B*C; here B=(k-4)and C=4 resulting in -(x1)*(x2)=-[(k-4)]*(4); hence k-4 cannot equal zero since otherwise no real root exists due to multiplication by zero. Thus k≠4 implying it doesn't include four as a possible value because when plugged into quadratic would produce zero multiplied term making impossible solving via square completing methodology leading contradiction assuming existence without further analysis required showing validity within range [-500,500] confirmation

0.user_question: Find the number of integer values of $k$ in the closed interval $[-500,500]$ for which the equation $\log(kx)=2\log(x+2)$ has exactly one real solution.

subanswer.text: Simplifying yields \[\log(kx)=\log((x+2)^2).\] Taking exponentials, we have \(kx=(x+2)^2\). Expanding the right side gives \(kx=x^2+4x+4\). Rearranging terms, we arrive at the quadratic equation \(x^2+(4-k)x+4=0\). This means our focus should now shift towards analyzing how many different k-values allow only one root (or zero roots), as specified by [this formula](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadratic_equation#Number_of_real_roots_as_function_of_the_discriminant). Specifically, if \(\Delta = b^2 - 4ac\) where [\(\Delta > 0\)], then there exist _two distinct solutions_. However, since we want just *one* or no solutions (\(\Delta = 0\) or negatives)\[\Delta = -(4)(4)-4k<0,\]\[-16-4k<0,\]\[-4-k<0.\]This implies:\[k>-4.\]So any positive integral value greater than –4 allows precisely one intersection; otherwise, there’re either none (*if* `k` equals –4 **OR** below `-4`) or multiple intersections (*whenever*) `k` falls within `[–4, –6)`. Because integers need not necessarily fall exclusively inside those ranges above...we consider them separately! Therefore, let's count up starting backward until reaching negative infinity but stop before hitting anything lesser(*i.* Negative infinities don’t factor); next comes every single whole unit increment over '--->'; lastly include everything strictly underneath & equal(*) To conclude…there exists nine separate groups containing varying quantities per group based upon whether their boundaries align equally opposed (`<=`) versus unequally opposite(`<`). They range through five sizes inclusive(): `(no members)`, `{1 member}`, `{2 members}`, `{3members}`, `{4members}` And so forth till eventually encompassing infinitely large sets composed entirely outta nothingness!\*\*\*{five possible scenarios}\*\*\*. In conclusion though—remember your initial assignment required finding exact figures rather than estimating relative occurrences using general observations alone hence why careful attention must still apply despite apparent simplicity behind presented information!) ost_step.2: Using Vieta’s formulas, let p represent the product of roots (\$q\) represents root multiplied together.) Let b = |4−k|.\[ q=-p/b\]Substituting back using our original problem,\[\begin{aligned} k &= -\left(\text {sum}\right)/\left|\text {difference}\right| \quad& =\dfrac{-a_{1}}{c}\\ & =-\dfrac{-(4)}{(4-k)}=\dfrac{4}{(4-k)}\end{aligned}\] Substituting new value:\[\begin{array}{|rclcrccl|} \hline & n&\ge&&500 && m &\le& (-500)&\\ \hline Q&= \left\{ y \mid 4^{\frac{1}{4}} (m)+4^{-\frac{1}{4}}(n)\leq 500\right\}    &         &      &       &        &          &     \\ C &= \left \{ z \mid -(4)^{\frac{1}{4}} (n)-4^{-\frac{1}{4}}(m)>-500\right\}           &                                &            &             &

direct_answer.text: To simplify the logarithmic equation \(\log(kx)=\log[(x+2)^2]\), we can equate the arguments since logs with the same base cancel out as follows: \(kx = (x+2)^2\). Expanding the right side yields \(kx = x^2 + 4x + 4\). Rearranging terms leads to a quadratic equation: \(x^2 + (4-k)x + 4 = 0\). For this equation to have no real solutions, its discriminant, \(b^2 - 4ac\), must be less than zero. Here, \(a = 1\), \(b = 4-k\), and \(c = 4\). Thus, \((4-k)^2 - 4*1*4 < 0\). Simplifying further, we obtain \(k^2 - 8k + 16 - 16 < 0\), leading to \(k^2 - 8k < 0\). Factoring gives us \(k(k - 8) < 0\). To determine how many integer values of \( k \) make the logarithmic equation \(\log(kx) = 2\log(x+2)\) have exactly one real solution within the interval [-500, 500], let's proceed systematically:

Firstly, simplify the original equation using properties of logarithms:
\[\log(kx) = \log((x+2)^2)\]
Since logs of equal arguments imply equality of those expressions, set them equal to each other inside the log function:
\[kx = (x + 2)^2\]
Next, expand and rearrange terms to form a quadratic equation:
\[kx = x^2 + 4x + 4\]
Move everything to one side to match the standard form \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\):
\[x^2 + (4-k)x + 4 = 0\]

direct_answer.text:
To solve the problem, let's start by simplifying the original equation:
$\log(kx) = 2\log(x+2)$
Using logarithmic properties, specifically the product rule ($\log_b(mn) = \log_b(m) + \log_b(n)$):
$\log(kx) - \log(x+2) = 2\log(x+2)$
Now, use the quotient rule ($log_b\left(\dfrac{m}{n}\right) = log_b(m) - log_b(n)$):
$\log\left(\dfrac{kx}{(x+2)^2}\right) = 0$
This implies that the argument inside the log function equals 1:
$\dfrac{kx}{(x+2)^2} = 1$
Cross multiply to isolate kx:
$(x+2)^2 = kx$
Expand the left side and bring all other terms to the right side:
$x^2 + 4x + 4 = kx$
Rearrange it into standard quadratic form ax² + bx + c = 0

1.subquestion: Simplify the right side of the equation using logarithmic properties.

subanswer.text: First let us look into what each term represents: Let $$a=b^{b}$$ Now taking natural logs on both sides $$\ln\left({a}\right)=\ln\left({b}^{b}\right)$$ Using property of powers when applying log function it simplifies as$$\ln\left({a}\right)=b\cdot \ln\left({b}\right)$$ Similarly,$ab=ba$Now considering another condition $$e^{\log b}=b$$ Taking exponentiate power to base e.$$e^{\log ab}={ab}$$Applying ln now,\begin{align*}\ln& {eb}^{\log ab}\\&=(\log ab)\times\ln e\\&=\color{blue}{\log ab\times 1}\end{align*}Since any real nonzero value times one remains unchanged$\Rightarrow \ln\left({ab}\right)=\color{blue}{\log ab}$

direct_answer.text: Let's first simplify the original equation $\log(kx)=2\log(x+2)$ using logarithmic properties. By employing the property $\log_{b}(MN)=\log_{b}(M)+\log_{b}(N)$, we get \[\log(kx)=\log((x+2)^{2}).\]We recognize here $(\log x)(K) = K$, so our simplified equation becomes \[ kx=(x+2)^{2}, \]which expands further to \[ kx=x^2+4x+4.\]This rearranges to give you the quadratic equation \[\boxed{x^2-(k-4)x+4=0}.\] For such quadratics equations, having unique roots requires discriminant ($D$) equal zero - i.e., underneath square root inside parenthesis equals zero; thus leading to \(B^{2}-4AC=0\). Here [\(A=1\)], [\(B=-(k-4)\)], [\(C=4\)]. Solving yields \(\boxed{k=2}\) being your required integer fulfillment within limits [-500,500]. Thus leaving countless other integers outside

subanswer.text: Applying the property $[\log ab] = [\log a] + [\log b]$ , we have $$ [(\log (kx))] = [( \log k)] + [\log x].$$ Squaring both side yields $$\begin{aligned}[r]&[(\log (kx))]²\\&=([\log k] + [\log x])². \\ &= [\log k]² + 2[\log k][\log x]+[\log x]² && \text{(using binomial theorem.) } \end{aligned}$$ Also applying $[A^2B^2=AB]$,we know $$\begin{aligned}&[\log x]²=[(\log x)(2)]&& \text{(since $\log \, A =\log B$)}\\ &=\log (x^2) . \quad &\text{Hence}, [\log (kx)]²=[\log (x^2 )]+2[\log K][\log x]. \end{aligned}$$ But also recall again that $\log_{d}(c^{-1})$ equals $-\log _{d}(c)$, so rewrite further \[\begin{aligned}[r]\qquad&\Rightarrow [\log ((xy)^{-1})]=[\log (y^{-1})\times {\log (x^{-1}))}]=-2[\log ({x}+\log (y)).\end{aligned} \] Therefore combining everything together finally yield:\begin{aligned}[r]\qquad&[(~\log (K×X)~)²=&[\log (x²)+2[\log k](\log x)−2[\log X](\log x)],\\& (=[\log (xy)])², &(applying \;distributive\; law)\\&=&[\log ((xy)⁻¹)]²,\;\therefore&=[-\log (xy)²],\\& =[-2\log x -2\log y],\end{aligned}This means no matter what choice made for integer 'k', every term containing 'k' gets cancelled off at either end during comparing equality. Hence final statement reads:"For any real positive nonzero '$x'$ such that ${|k|<500}$, only single ($\{x,y\}$ pair exist where $\{x,\,y\}={1,\,x}^{-1}$)"which leads directly onto next section...so far I understand but why not just skip ahead?? direct_answer.text:
To analyze the impact of choosing different \( k \) values within the interval \( -500 \leq k \leq 500 \), let's first consider the original equation derived from the previous discussion:

\[ ([\log (kx)])^2 = [\log (x^2) + 2[\log k][\log x] - 2[\log x][\log x]] = -2[\log (xy)] \]

Simplifying the right side of the equation, we get:

\[ -2[\log (x) + \log (y)] = -2[\log (xy)] \]

Since \(\log (abc) = \log (a) + \log (b) + \log (c)\), it follows that the left side represents twice the natural logarithm of some value whose exponentiation would equal \( xy \). Thus, regardless of whether \( k \) takes on various integer values within the specified interval, each combination corresponds uniquely to pairs \((x, y)\) defined by \( \{x,\,y\}={1,\,x}^{-1} \). It indicates consistency—the same relationship holds irrespective of chosen \( k \)
